sections.summary: Disbelievers express amazement at the prophetic warning, dismissing the **resurrection** as an impossibility once the body has become dust. Allah counters this by asserting His knowledge of the physical decay of bodies, which is meticulously recorded in His **comprehensive book**.

The text directs humanity to observe the architecture of the sky and the stability of the earth, provided as a **reminder** for every penitent worshiper. These natural phenomena, including the revival of **dead land** through rainfall, serve as physical proof for the reality of the coming **resurrection** [423–424].

Previous nations such as the people of Noah, Aad, and Pharaoh are cited for their rejection of messengers and the subsequent realization of divine threats. Allah argues that if He was not fatigued by the **first creation**, He is certainly capable of producing a **new creation**.

Allah asserts His proximity to the human being, knowing even the **whispers of the soul**, and describes the presence of two angelic **receivers** who record every uttered word. This establishment of constant surveillance emphasizes absolute **accountability** for every individual.

The narrative depicts the **daze of death** and the subsequent sounding of the Trumpet, leading to the **Day of Judgment** where every soul is accompanied by a witness. Disbelievers and aggressors who fabricated other gods are cast into **Hell**, a destination that perpetually asks for more inmates [424–425].

**Paradise** is brought near to those who were mindful and arrived with a **repentant heart**, fearing the Most Gracious inwardly. These inhabitants enter the **Day of Eternity** in peace, finding all their desires fulfilled and receiving additional bounties from their Lord.

The Prophet is exhorted to maintain **patience** and engage in constant **glorification** while awaiting the Day of Emergence, when the earth will crack to release the dead. Allah affirms He is the ultimate controller of **life and death**, instructing the Prophet to serve as a warner rather than a dictator [425–426].
